content: top-­ down handspun hat with a nice flat top by heidi nick this hat pattern is nothing fancy it s just the result of lots of experimenting on my part it s more of a recipe than a pattern i m leaving needles/yarn/gauge up to you but here is what usually works for me i use two 24 circular needles to cast on only because i have a ton of these needles lying around but of course you could use dpns or a shorter circular needle then i switch to one circular needle once i have several inches done with a dk weight handspun i generally increase to 88 stitches on #6-­ 8 needles with a heavy sport weight i generally increase to 104 or 112 stitches on #3-­ 5 needles the nice thing about working top-­ down is that if you re not sure how many stitches to use you can try the hat on as you re knitting use two circular needles for this so the stitches don t slide off what makes the nice flat top is the increasing every round for the first 7 rounds or so then switching to increases every other round ending with several inches of rib makes the fit very forgiving good for pretty much any size head i find that a finished length of about 11 is just about right for me it gives a lot of brim to fold back if you prefer less brim then maybe go for about 10 using judy s magic cast-­ on cast on 8 stitches 4 on each of 2 needle here is a link to a youtube video showing judy s magic cast on https //www youtube com/watch v=1pmxrdz-­ cwo round 1 knit 8 stitches round 2 knit in the front and back of each stitch 16 stitches round 3 *knit 1 knit in the front and back of the next stitch *
